sections.heading: Overview
content: Paula A. Johnson, MD, MPH, is the executive director of the Connors Center for Women’s Health and Gender Biology and chief of the Division of Women’s Health at Brigham and Women’s Hospital, where she is responsible for developing an interdisciplinary research, education, and clinical program in women’s health. The mission of the center is to improve the health of women and transform medicine so that knowledge of gender and its effects are routinely applied in clinical practice.

Johnson is a cardiologist and is the founder and director of the Center for Cardiovascular Disease in Women at Brigham and Women’s Hospital, which is part of the Connors Center. Her work at the Center for Cardiovascular Disease in Women has been dedicated to developing new strategies for primary and secondary prevention of heart disease in women and to spearhead research that furthers knowledge of the impact of gender on heart disease. She is recognized as a national expert in the area of defining and understanding the quality of cardiology care for women and minorities. Her research has focused on understanding disparities in healthcare for women and minorities.

Previously, Johnson served as the director of the Department of Quality Management Services at Brigham and Women’s, where she was responsible for developing and executing hospital-wide programs to improve the quality of care for patients.

Johnson is a graduate of Harvard University and Radcliffe College. She received her MD and MPH degrees from Harvard in 1985. She then went on to complete her residency in internal medicine at Brigham and Women’s Hospital, where she also completed a fellowship in cardiovascular disease and served as chief medical resident.

Johnson is the recipient of several awards recognizing her contributions in women’s and minority health including the Abigail Adams Award from the Massachusetts Women’s Political Caucus, which recognizes and honors Massachusetts women leaders who have demonstrated through their work and/or their community activism an outstanding commitment to the realization of equal political, economic, and social rights for women. She was named one of the “Top Doctors in Boston” for women in 2001 and one of the “Top Doctors” in 2002 by Boston Magazine . Johnson serves on several not-for-profit boards including Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts (where she served as chairwoman), and the Schwartz Center. She is a wife and mother of two.
